Expectation1: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation1: The site-wide evacuation alarm has just sounded, and you must stop everything and proceed to the muster point immediately.
Expectation2: Participate in civic life by staying informed, voting, and giving constructive feedback
Situation2: A ballot measure affecting their block closes in two hours at the nearby polling place.
Story: The shrill site alarm jolts me from my focus, and I drop my tools, heart pounding. Protocol is clear: leave everything, head straight to the muster point, no exceptions. My foreman’s voice echoes in my mind—safety first, always. But as I join the stream of workers, my phone buzzes with a reminder: the polling place closes in two hours. Today’s ballot measure could change the zoning on my block, maybe even affect my rent. I promised myself I’d vote, be the kind of citizen who shows up, who cares. But now, stuck behind the chain-link fence, I can’t just slip away. My team counts on me to follow the rules, to be accounted for. My city counts on me to make my voice heard. I feel the weight of both expectations pressing in, sweat prickling my neck, torn between duty to my crew and duty to my community.
